column1: Gorodets (Russian: Городе́ц) is a town and the administrative center of Gorodetsky District in Nizhny Novgorod Oblast

column4: 53 kilometers (33 mi) northwest of Nizhny Novgorod
column5: the administrative center of the oblast. Population: 30

column1: == History ==
The town was founded in 1152 by Prince Yury Dolgoruky (also the founder of Moscow) as a large fortress on the Volga River
column2: the first Russian fortress in today's Nizhny Novgorod Oblast. It was a starting point for numerous campaigns of the princes of Vladimir and Suzdal against Volga Bulgaria. In 1216
column3: Yury II of Vladimir was dethroned by his brother and exiled here. In 1239
column4: the town was burned to the ground by Batu Khan's army. Folk tradition identifies Gorodets with Little Kitezh
column5: a legendary town destroyed by the Mongols.

column7: the town was overshadowed by the neighboring Nizhny Novgorod but continued as the third largest town of Nizhny Novgorod Principality until 1408
column8: when Edigu razed it to the ground.

column1: == Administrative and municipal status ==
Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: Gorodets serves as the administrative centre of Gorodetsky District. As an administrative division

column4: the town of district significance of Gorodets is incorporated within Gorodetsky Municipal District as Gorodets Urban Settlement.

column1: === Transportation ===
The electric railroad branch from Nizhny Novgorod ends in Zavolzhye; but there is a road connection over the hydro dam
